column4: GTT to sell infrastructure unit to I Squared for $2.15 billion
column5: (Reuters) - Telecommunications provider GTT Communications GTT.N said on Friday it would sell its infrastructure unit to I Squared Capital in a $2.15 billion deal that would boost the private equity firm's plan to create a global fiber-optic network.
column6: The unit’s network, which transmits data through light and powers high-speed internet, spans over 103 cities in Europe and North America with three transatlantic subsea cables. The network opens new markets to I Squared Capital as demand for telecommuting, remote classes and other virtual activities grows during the coronavirus pandemic.
column7: GTT shares jumped as much as 36% on the news but pared gains to 10% shortly after midday. GTT said it would use proceeds to pay down the $3.2 billion in long-term debt built up after an acquisition spree over the last decade.GTT had been exploring the sale since last year, which it expected to deliver $370 million to $390 million in revenue with comparable earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) of $160 million to $180 million.
column8: “It’s a European and U.S. asset base and it’s very resilient,” I Squared Capital Managing Partner Gautam Bhandari said in an interview. “Even in the middle of the pandemic, globally, we are seeing incredible amounts of bandwidth usage.”
column9: I Squared Capital said it planned to expand the network to other European cities through investment and add-on acquisitions.
column10: Fiber-optics are gaining investor interest as wireless providers build out networks for 5G, the next-generation wireless technology.
column11: In 2017, I Squared Capital bought Hutchison Global Communications, the Hong Kong-based fiber optic company for HK$14.5 billion ($1.9 billion).
column12: “This is part of our digital strategy where we are effectively taking network assets fiber network assets in Asia, Europe and the U.S., with the intention of growing them,” said Bhandari.

column4: GTT Communications to sell infrastructure unit for about $2 bln
column5: Oct 16 (Reuters) - GTT Communications said on Friday it would sell its infrastructure unit to I Squared Capital for nearly $2 billion. (Reporting by Munsif Vengattil in Bengaluru Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

column4: MIDEAST STOCKS-Saudi hits one-month high; Global Telecom drags Egypt down
column5: * Rajhi, SABIC send Saudi to highest level in a month
column6: * Alinma jumps 6 pct on higher proposed annual dividend
column9: RIYADH, Dec 2 (Reuters) - Saudi Arabia’s stock market closed on Sunday at its highest level since early November amid solid gains by a number of blue chips, while Egypt’s bourse closed in negative territory, dragged down by Global Telecom’s huge losses.
column10: United Arab Emirates markets were closed for a public holiday while other Gulf markets were mixed in lacklustre trade.
column11: The Saudi index jumped 1.8 percent, recording its highest level since Nov. 4 as Al Rajhi Bank rose 2.5 percent, and petrochemical giant SABIC added 2.2 percent.
column12: Alinma Bank surged 6.0 percent after proposing a 1.0 riyals ($0.26) dividend for 2018, up from 0.8 riyal for 2017.
column13: Out of 180 Saudi stocks traded, 162 advanced and only 13 declined.
column14: In Egypt, the main index fell 1.3 percent amid a wide sell-off with only two of its 30 stocks advancing. Commercial International Bank fell 1.9 percent.
column15: Global Telecom, one of the most heavily traded stocks in the market, was the main drag, plummeting 12.4 percent after its board approved increasing issued capital by 11.18 billion pounds ($625.5 million) through issuing 19.28 billion new shares.
column16: In Qatar, the index lost 0.5 percent on big declines by banking stocks, with losers outnumbering gainers by 23 to 17.
column17: Qatar National Bank lost 1.3 percent and Qatar Islamic Bank fell 1.6 percent, Qatar Commercial Bank went down 2.1 percent and Masraf Al Rayan lost 1.1 percent.
column18: Kuwait, Oman and Bahrain were flat.
column19: * The index jumped 1.8 percent to 7,845 points.
column20: * The index fell 0.5 percent to 10,317 points.
column21: * The index was flat at 5,318 points.
column22: * The index fell 1.3 percent to 13,150 points.
column23: * The index edged up 0.2 percent to 1,332 points.
column24: * The index was flat at 4,418 points. ($1 = 3.7516 riyals) ($1 = 17.8750 Egyptian pounds) (Reporting by Marwa Rashad; Editing by Mark Heinrich)
